coredata.dc:title: Molecular structure of nickelcyclopentadienylnitrosyl in condensed phases studied by EXAFS
coredata.dc:creator: Chen, Lin X.
Bowman, Michael K.
Thurnauer, Marion C.
Lytle, Farrel.W.
Norris, James R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The molecular structure of nickelcyclopentadienylnitrosyl (NiCpNO) in hexane liquid solution and in polystyrene film has been studied by EXAFS. EXAFS parameters from reference compounds and from theoretical calculations which assume normal, single scattering for NiCpNO EXAFS data analysis failed to fit the experimental data. This fact indicates a strong forward focusing effect in NiCpNO due to a linear or nearly linear configuration of NiO. In such a case, multiple scattering must be included in the data analysis. Curve fittings with structural parameters derived from reference compounds with a similar linear configuration have given satisfactory agreement and reasonable distances between Ni and other atoms in the molecule. The NiN, NiC and NiO distances are determined to be 1.65, 2.16 and 2.77 Å, respectively.

USA Received 3August1992; in final form 17September 1992 The molecular structure of nickelcyclopeatadienylnitrosyl (NiCpNO) in hexane liquid solution and in polystyrene film has been studied by EXAFS. EXAFS parameters from reference compounds and from theoretical calculations which assume normal, single scattering for NiCpNO EXAFS data analysis failed to fit the experimental data. This fact indicates a strong forward focusing effect in NiCpNO due to a linear or nearly linear configuration of Ni N O. In such a case, multiple scattering must be included in the data analysis. Curve fittings with structural parameters derived from reference compounds with a similar linear configuca- tiun have given satisfactory agreement and reasonable distances between Ni and other atoms in the molecule. The Ni N, Ni C and Ni O distances are determined to be 1.65, 2.16 and 2.77 A, respectively. 1. Introduction Almost two decades ago, an FUR study [1] on nickelcyolopentadienylnitrosyl (NiCpNO) in an ar- gon matrix revealed a photoinduced, long-lived in- termediate upon irradiation with wavelength <280 nm. The vibfational frequency of the N O stretch in this intermediate shifted from the ground state value of 1825 to 1392cm 1 [11. We also observe a similar photoinduced reaction of NiCpNO in alkane matrix at 15 K. Crichton and Rest [1] suggested that NiCpNO formed a photoinduced charge-separated intermediate with NO character, because the fre- quency of 1392 cm 1 is characteristic of the NO stretch in an Ar matrix [2]. That the ground state can be regenerated by irradiation with wavelength between 290 and 350 nm excludes permanent pho- todissociation. According to molecular orbital the- ory, the negative charge on the NO arising from the photoinduced charge separation would induce a con- formation change of Ni N O from linear to bent [31. The detailed relationship between this postu- Correspondence to: JR. Norris, Chemistry Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, USA. lated bent configuration and the long lifetime of the intermediate is yet to be understood. Direct mea- surements of the bond distances in both the ground and the excited states are needed to verify the nature of this reversible photo-transformation. In order to solve the structure of the photoinduced intermediate in NiCpNO, an accurate structure for the ground state must be determined first. Thus this paper deals with the ground state as revealed by EXAFS. NiCpNO has served as a model compound for monocyclopentadienyl it complexes as well as for transition-metal complexes with nitrosyl. Although its molecular structure has been studied by various methods including microwave spectroscopy, FUR, and NMR [1,4 6], no X-ray crystallographic data with atomic resolution has been published. In the gas phase microwave spectroscopy [4] of NiCpNO has provided a high-resolution molecular structure and confirmed its C5,, symmetry. However, many reac- tions of this compound occur in condensed phases, thus it is desirable to establish the molecular struc- ture of NiCpNO in such environments. EXAFS is a useful method for the determination of short-range molecular structure in non-crystalline forms. We present here EXAFS studies of the ground-state 290 0009-2614/92/S 05.00 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. Molecular structure of nickelcyclopentadienylnitrosyl in condensed phases studied by EXAFS Volume 200, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 December 1992 structure of NiCpNO in a hydrocarbon solvent and a polymer film. In addition to the structure deter- mination, we will discuss the data analysis including the multiple scattering effect in NiCpNO. The NiCpNO structure determined by EXAFS in the condensed phase will be compared with that in the gas phase from microwave spectroscopy [4]. 2. Experimental The nickelcyclopentadienylnitrosyl (NiCpNO), purchased from Strem Chemicals (Massachusetts, USA), was a gift from Professor Gregory Hillhouse (University of Chicago). UV grade n-hexane was from Baxter. The polystyrene was from SP2 Scien- tific Polymer Products (New York, USA). Solvents and NiCpNO were used without further purifica- tion. Sample preparation was conducted in a nitro- gen glove box. The concentration was approximately 0.8 M for the liquid solution sample. The polymer film sample was made by dissolving polystyrene in toluene and mixing with NiCpNO. Then the poly- mer solution was spread on a piece of mylar film and dried under nitrogen. The thickness of the films was about 0.2 mm. Two reference compounds, nickelo- cene (NiCp2) and nickel(1I) oxide (NiO), were purchased from Aldrich Chemicals and each was mixed separately with Hardman extra fast setting epoxy sandwiched between mylar sheets. The EXAFS data were collected at beam line X23A2 of the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS) at Brookhaven National Laboratory. A sil- icon (311) crystal monochromator was used to scan the X-ray spectrum. Ion chambers were used for de- tecting the intensities of the incident and the trans- mitted X-ray. An ion chamber X-ray fluorescence detector was used with cobalt filter. For all samples, both absorption and fluorescence data were col- lected in the range from 100 to 1000 eV relative to E0 of nickel K shell (8333 eV). The edge energy was calibrated with a nickel foil EXAFS scan pre- ceding each series of sample data collection. Three regions were defined in each scan with boundaries of 100, 20, 30 and 1000 eV and intervals of 2 eV, 0.5 eV and 0.05k, where k=~J4i~m(E Eo)fh. Three samples were measured, NiCpNO in hexane solution at room temperature, NiCpNO/polystyrene film at room temperature and at low temperature ( 130 C). Ten scans (20 min each) were collected and added for the liquid solution sample, and five scans (20 min each) for the film samples. Low-tem- perature data collection was conducted by passing cold nitrogen gas through a hollow copper sample holder. The sample temperature was about 131 to l37~ C. 3. Data analysis The background removal and curve fitting of the data were carried out with the Boeing EXAPLT (background removal) and EXAFIT (curve fitting) programs. The edge energy (8333 eV) was cali- brated for each sample relative to the peak in the first derivative of nickel foil spectrum taken before the sample spectrum. The spectra were deglitched when necessary. The data normalization was performed by fitting the background to a polynomial spline with 5 or 6 regions, judging by the result after Fourier trans- form (FIT). The pre-edge background was removed with a linear function of k determined by two points before the edge transition. No McMaster correction was used because the deviation for low Z back-scat- tering atoms is small. A k3 weighted FIT was used in order to get the best separation between the shells. The curve fittings were carried out for a one-shell fit (the third shell Ni O) only) and for three-shell si- multaneous fits for the N, C and O distances. The EXAFS spectra of reference compounds NiCp3 and NiO were analyzed in a similar fashion. The phases for Ni O and Ni C scattering pairs were extracted from back Fourier transforms of the spectra, based on their crystal structures [7,8]. The distances for Ni O and Ni C in NiO and NiCp2 were 2.0876 and 2.196 A., respectively. Due to lack of a suitable ref- erence compound for the Ni N shell, the amplitudes and phases of C in NiCp2 and O in NiO were used respectively for the Ni N distance determination. The values of the Ni N distance was determined from averaging the two different fittings using NiO and NiCp2. This method may cause a slight inac- curacy in the results. The linear configuration of Ni N O found from the gas-phase microwave spectroscopy measure- ments [4] indicated that multiple scattering effects 291 Volume 200, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 December 1992 would have to be included in the data analysis of the Ni O scattering. Indeed, the phases extracted from NiO (the nearest neighbors) and those from theo- retical calculations accounting for only single scat- tering [9,10] could not fit the experimental EXAFS spectra. In order to solve this phase problem associated with the linear Ni N O bond, two approaches were used. The first was to fit the Ni O scattering using phases extracted from a reference compound with similar central and back-scattering atoms as well as a similar linear configuration as Ni N O. Based on known structural parameters, the Co4(CO ) 12 EXAFS spec- trum (collected previously by Lytle) was used as a reference for Ni O shell. Its structure has been solved to atomic resolution by X-ray diffraction [7,8]. Each of the nine terminal carbonyl groups forms a nearly linear configuration with the Co C bond. In addi- tion, this compound contains three bridging car- bonyl groups. The Co O distances in Co4 (CO)12 are inhomogeneous with an average distance of 2.93 A. Yet the FT of EXAFS spectrum for Co4(CO)12 showed three well-separated peaks corresponding to Co C, Co Co and Co O distances. In particular, the third peak for Co O is narrow and symmetric. Thus, extracting the phase with the average Co O distance calculated from the crystal structure seems reason- able. The effect of the non-uniform distances in the reference compound on the accuracy of the distance determination is discussed in section 4. The other approach to measure the Ni O distance in NiCpNO used a theoretical calculation that in- cluded multiple scattering. Teo developed a method for this approach [Il], which was generalized by Boland et al. [12]. Their calculations included con- tributions from all possible scattering paths in a tri- atomic system A B C, where A, B and C are the cen- tral atom, intervening atom and terminal atom, re- spectively. The apparent back scattering from C de- pends on the angle of L. ABC. It should be pointed out that Teo s and Boland et al. s calculations [9,10] are identical for a linear geometry of ABC. Only when t ABC deviates considerably from 1800 are the two calculations different. The three peaks as r increases are from N, C and O, respectively. The amplitude of the third peak is obviously much larger than 1 / 5 that of the second, indicating forward focusing arising from multiple scattering. A proper reference compound for the Ni N bond was not available. Therefore, one Ni N distance of 1.700 0.005 A was determined using the C ampli- tude envelope and phases from NiCp2 and another distance of 1.597 0.00 5 A was obtained using those of O from the reference compound NiO. These er- rors are the difference between two sets of raw data under duplicate conditions and do not necessarily reflect the accuracy of the bond distance determi- nation. The absolute accuracy for all distance deter- minations will be discussed below. Assuming the back-scattering amplitude and phases can be ap- proximated as linear functions of atomic number from C toO (Z=6 8) in the entire k region, the N back-scattering envelope and phases could be inter- polated from those of C and O. Thus, the Ni N dis- tance of 1.65 A, averaged from the values obtained using the Ni C and the Ni O references, is nearly what would be obtained using a Ni N reference compound. For the second shell, the Ni C distance was determined to be 2.163 0.002 A using param- eters from NiCp2. The result of the third shell, the Ni 0 distance is 2.768 0.004 A using the O back scattering amplitude envelope from NiO (Ni to the nearest O, the first shell) and the phases extracted from Co4(CO)12 (the Co O shell, average distance 2.93 A). Fig. 2 shows the result of the liquid solution sample at room temperature. However, errors at- tributable to the lack of a suitable Ni N reference and to the noise in the experimental spectrum could be greater than indicated above; consequently, based on past experience we estimate errors for our Ni C and Ni N distances to be 0.02 and 0.04 A, respec- tively. The coordination numbers for the first shell (Ni N) and the second shell (Ni C) were approx- imately 1: 5, as expected. However, the coordination number for the third shell (Ni O), which is largely due to the multiple scattering, is about 2.5 times of that for Ni N shell (using O amplitude envelope from NiO as a reference for both shells). The errors most likely to occur in the Ni O dis- tance determination are from the inhomogeneous Co O distances in the reference compound Co4(CO)12. We used the phase correction factor co~ only in the calculation. The fitting result for a linear configuration gives the Ni O distance of 2.814 A and an rms deviation of 0.239 of the fit with k3 weight- ing, whereas that for a 300 bent configuration gives a Ni O distance of 2.808 A and an rms deviation of the fit of 0.318 with k3 weighting. The latter shows a systematic deviation from the experimental data in the low-k region. Thus, the observed EXAFS spec- trum is indicative of a linear configuration for Ni N O. One of the most important results from the microwave spectroscopy of NiCpNO [4] is the con- firmation of its C5~, symmetry, implying a linear con- figuration of Ni N O. Although possessing some- what lower structural resolution than gas-phase microwave spectroscopy EXAFS finds the same lin- ear configuration. The results for the Ni O distance with the theoretical model is close to those obtained from the reference compounds. The difference of 0.04 A is comparable to that obtained in the test fitting for NiO with the reference compound and with the theoretical phases from McKale s calculation [8]. S. Conclusions Our fitting results suggested that NiCpNO has a nearly linear configuration of Ni N O. The dis- tances of Ni C, Ni N, and Ni O are 2.16 0.02, 1.65 0.04 and 2.77 0.04 A, respectively. The dis- tances agree well with the results from the micro- wave spectroscopy except that EXAFS gives a 0.05 A longer Ni C distance. The difference is attributed to the solvent interactions. Also, the disorder of the structure is reduced in the polymer film. We have systematically fit the experimental data with different parameters derived from reference compounds and theory. The results of the fitting in- dicate that a significant EXAFS spectral change should be observed if a photoinduced distance change is no less than 0.04 A, or a bending of about 30 . Thus, EXAFS studies to characterize the photoin- duced intermediate of NiCpNO are in progress. and the distance in the condensed phases (1.65 A) is within the accuracy of the EXAFS. The Ni C distances in liquid solution NiCpNO appear to be 0.05 A longer than those reported in gas phase [4], but are closer to the Ni C distances de- temsined by X-ray diffraction (2.20 A) of the bis- cyclopentadienyl complex, NiCp2. Considering the structural similarity between NiCp2 and NiCpNO, the Ni C distance obtained in NiCpNO using C back scattering from NiCp2 should be rather accurate. Previous vibrational spectroscopy studies of Ni- CpNO in different solvents [13] suggested that the similarities in the ring-metal bonds for bis- and mono-cyclopentadienyl compounds result from the similarity in the metal carbon bonding characteris- tics. Our EXAFS results in the condensed phase sup- port this observation, because a 0.03 A difference is comparable to the error limit of EXAFS technique. Cox and Bnttain [4] gave an explanation for the discrepancy of the Ni C bond distances in nickelo- cene and in gas-phase NiCpNO as a result of an extra electron pair occupying antibonding orbitais in NiCp2. This argument may still hold for our results for the Ni C distance which is 0.03 A shorter than that in nickelocene. However, we believe that the difference in the Ni C distance between the gas phase and the liquid so- lution is a real effect and may be attributed to the interactions with the solvent molecules. The N O bond length, if Ni N O is collinear, is 1.12 A in the hexane solution, well within the bond-length range of 1.1 1.2 A of most organometallic nitrosyl com- pounds [14]. However, the NO distance in liquid solution is 0.04 A shorter than that of the gas phase (1.16 A), indicating an increase of bond order due to the interaction with solvent molecules. According to the previous studies by Teo [il] and Boland et al. [121, the apparent back-scattering am- plitude and phase of an atom should differ signifi- cantly from those of the normal single scattering case, if the forward focusing effect due to the multiple scattering is present. Thus, it is possible to obtain the molecular geometry information from the EXAFS spectrum by using this effect. As a way to explore the feasibility of applying the theory to the experimental data, we conducted such an analysis for the third shell O with the phases calculated from Teo s model [9]. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The molecular structure of nickelcyclopentadienylnitrosyl (NiCpNO) in hexane liquid solution and in polystyrene film has been studied by EXAFS. EXAFS parameters from reference compounds and from theoretical calculations which assume normal, single scattering for NiCpNO EXAFS data analysis failed to fit the experimental data. This fact indicates a strong forward focusing effect in NiCpNO due to a linear or nearly linear configuration of NiO. In such a case, multiple scattering must be included in the data analysis. Curve fittings with structural parameters derived from reference compounds with a similar linear configuration have given satisfactory agreement and reasonable distances between Ni and other atoms in the molecule. The NiN, NiC and NiO distances are determined to be 1.65, 2.16 and 2.77 Å, respectively.
